2.39 p.m.

    The Chairman: Development Estimates of Expenditure of the State of Singapore for the year 1965, as contained in Paper Cmd. 25 of 1964. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head of expenditure as it appears in the third column of the Summary of Expenditure on page 7 of the Paper.

    Dealing now with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Perhaps for the convenience of Members, and in order that we might not have difficulties over the content of the speeches which Members will make, I have to inform Members that they must not repeat arguments which have been used on the Estimates or on matters which they had rightfully discussed on the Estimates. These are Development Estimates and the debate should proceed on a completely different line from that of yesterday. If Members will keep that in mind, we will make great progress.

Column: 677



    Head D 01 -

    The Chairman: The first amendment is Head D 01 - Land Office. There is one amendment standing in the names of three Members, Messrs. Ong Lian Teng, Tan Cheng Tong and Ong Eng Guan. As Mr Ong Lian Teng's amendment was received first, he will move the amendment first.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng (Bukit Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head D 01 be reduced by $100.

    I would like to raise two questions under this head. I hope the Minister concerned will give a reply. First, the Government's acquisition of land from 1st January, 1961, up to 30th of June, 1964. How much land was acquired by

Column: 678

the Government during this period? How much of it belonged to private land-owners and how much was military land? How much money was spent on them?

    Secondly, at what prices did the Government acquire private land? According to what standard did it acquire the land?

    The Chairman: Mr Tan Cheng Tong. The Member need not speak now if he does not want to. He may speak afterwards.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): I do not wish to speak now.

    The Chairman: Mr Ong Eng Guan?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan indicated dissent.

    The Chairman: Is the Prime Minister replying to this?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Yes, Mr Speaker, Sir. If the Member wishes to have the information he seeks of a detailed nature from 1961 to 1964, I suggest he table a question in that respect. Under this particular head of expenditure, I am here to explain why we have put in a vote of $10 million for acquisition of private lands for public purposes for the year 1965.

    As for the assessment of valuation, I think really he ought to consult his legal adviser. The law on the acquisition of land is quite clear. There is at present before a Select Committee of the Assembly a new Land Acquisition Bill some provisions of which may well have to be altered, or otherwise provisions will have to be made in the constitutional articles relating to acquisition of property, to remove any doubt as to the constitutional validity of some of these provisions. I do not wish to go into the intricacies of the law on land acquisition. The Member ought to know, from the representatives of his Party on the Select Committee, what is the present position and what we hope to do by an alteration of the law on land acquisition.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to make only a few comments under this heading. I feel that $10.5 million voted for the

Column: 679

acquisition of land is an over-estimated provision. My feeling is that not so much should be spent in 1965 because of the following reasons:

    The first reason is that there are periodical fire sites to be compulsorily acquired, and the Government pays to the land-owners only a small fraction, perhaps 10 per cent to 20 per cent of the market price of land, and pays to each fire victim a few tens of dollars as fire relief at the most. As far as my memory goes, there are already four big fires in the past four years, say, one fire for each year. If the Government has to pay the market value for these lands, adding to it the cost of removing the squatters, the inhabitants, and perhaps spend many years in removing them, then these lands in the four fire sites will cost the Government perhaps many hundreds of millions of dollars.

2.45 p.m.

    The second reason is that the resettlement compensation paid by the Government to villagers and squatters of lands, through the Housing Board, is much below that paid to squatters by private developers, perhaps only one-third or half of the market price of evicting the squatters.

    The third reason is that since the Government intends to pass its Land Acquisition Bill which, as the Prime Minister has just indicated, is even subject to certain alterations, the Government is only required to pay land-owners a small fraction of the market price of the land it has compulsorily acquired

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we know, under the provisions of the Bill, that the Government can pay land-owners perhaps even $500 per acre ---

    The Chairman: Order. The provisions of that Bill are now before the Select Committee and they should not be discussed here.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is for these reasons that I suggest to reduce the amount voted in the 1965 Budget. I feel that even $2½ million or $3 million would be sufficient for 1965.

Column: 680



    Mr Poh Ber Liak (Tampines)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Government acquires land, it does not pay attention to the welfare of the people concerned, nor does it look after their interest. In Paya Lebar, when the Government was repairing and extending the road, we saw that the residents along the road suffered much. About $300 compensation was paid to each family. In the past, these people had been renting attap houses. Every month ---

    The Chairman: Order. I have stated to hon. Members before the debate on the amendment started that the arguments used in the Estimates should not be used here. These are merely Development Estimates. What is in order is for the Member to ask the Government questions relating to the Development Estimates and not to discuss what arises out of them, what harm it will cause the people as a result therefrom. These matters should have been discussed yesterday and not today. So if the Member will please remember that and proceed with his speech.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in discussing the Development Estimates, we are concerned about the condition in which the people find themselves as a result of the acquisition of land by the Government, which has never been mentioned in the past. These people have been forced to remove because of Government's plan, or actual implementation of the plan, to extend and build roads there. Each family has been compensated to the sum of about $300. That is not enough to resolve their difficult position. Because in the past they have paid only a few dollars for rent ---

    The Chairman: Order. I do not want to stop the Member from making his speech. But I think he should pay some attention to the Chair's ruling. These are matters which properly should have been discussed yesterday or the day before, but not today.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, this matter which I am raising now was not raised yesterday or at any sitting in the past. This matter concerns ---

Column: 681



    The Chairman: Order. The Member should pay some attention to my ruling. These questions could have been raised yesterday and they should have been. If they were not, the Member will not raise them today on the Development Estimates.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I respect your ruling and I will not mention it any more, namely, the widening of Paya Lebar Road after acquisition of land there.

    I will now touch on another matter. The day before, I asked the Prime Minister certain questions. He did not give me a reply and the other Ministers were also not able to give me any satisfactory reply. This matter concerns a piece of land in Tampines 11 milestone which has been acquired by the Government. The Government have mentioned that this piece of land has been sublet to others. In fact, there is no proof and ---

    The Chairman: Order. These are Development Estimates for the year 1965. The hon. Member is touching upon a matter which relates to some items of expenditure which have already been incurred. He will see that he is completely out of order. He is not being relevant, in the first instance, to the topic under discussion. Will he proceed to some other point relevant to the issue before the House?

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think I will dwell on the question which I have just raised. I regret that the Prime Minister did not give me a reply point by point. Instead he touched on a certain Bill which is now before a Select Committee. The Bill is called the Land Acquisition (Amendment No. 2) Bill. I just want to know how much land the Government has acquired during the period I have indicated and at what prices. According to my knowledge, the land acquired by the Government is mostly private land. I would like to ask whether the Government intends also to acquire land belonging to the military authorities, such as the War Department and the Naval Base. In fact, the British military authorities

Column: 682

can be described as one of the largest landlords in Singapore and the Government dare not touch a single hair of these authorities. Judging by the vote of $10 million, if we have sufficient power to take back all or part of the land occupied by the military authorities, I believe there will be a great saving in this vote. The saving, I think, can be put to other development purposes. The Prime Minister dare not give me a full reply to my questions. I think he is afraid.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am really bewildered. On the one hand, I am urged by the Member for Hong Lim to give more money away to land-owners. He regrets the fact that Government has been able to acquire fire sites at 20 per cent the value of the land. I do not know what he really wants the Government to do. Take this public money, give it away to landlords who have fortuitously got their land cleared of tenants by fire, the burden of rehousing and resettling of whom falls upon the Government.

    On the other hand, I get the Barisan Sosialis Member for Bukit Panjang saying that it is a great pity that we should acquire private land. I would have thought that, being upholders of socialism, they would have been against private ownership of all land. That is one of the basic tenets. We accept the facts of life as they are. In so far as we can in our mixed economy, we try to mitigate the acquisition of fortuitous wealth by just the possession of land, particularly to prevent people from getting windfall gains as a result of public expenditure on development. But just in case people will accuse the Barisan of lack of anti-colonial fervour, back again we come to military land holdings. The Member has not read last year's proceedings of how we went to London and got back over 300 odd acres of land, and got a payment made of $10 million for use of T.O.L. land which belongs to the State and to which the Army had no title. What does he want us to do? Take back the Naval Base and close it down? Take back Changi Airfield and close it down? What are the facts of life?

Column: 683



    Do we really feel that it is wrong to have military bases and, therefore, we ought to scrap them and grow vegetables instead on them? These are dead issues, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    All I wish to say on the amount set aside, $10 million, is that it has been set aside for the last few years, and the expenditure over the 1960s - 1961, 1962, 1963 and 1964, up to November - has ranged between $4 million and $8 million, depending upon the exigencies that arise in the course of these years. Whilst we may not spend the $10 million, I think there is no particular harm in making provision for $10 million. I do not know what will happen in 1965. The estimation is that we shall be acquiring certain parcels of land for slum clearance and improvement schemes. We shall have to meet additional payments after a final survey of acquired land. There are certain contingency awards of legal costs which will have to be met arising out of the reference to court in respect of several objections made by owners under collective awards.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, my colleague, the Member for Bukit Panjang, has spoken on behalf of my Party to the effect that the Prime Minister should be urged to save on public funds and acquire more land belonging to the military authorities, so that some of it may be distributed for the use of farmers facing resettlement, so that they will have more land in which to do some farming. This is a good idea in my opinion. As far as I know, Mr Speaker, in my own constituency and in Sembawang constituency, or even in the Nee Soon area, there is a great deal of land occupied by the military authorities. This land has not been properly put to use and is deserted. Although there are some squatters scattered about in these areas, one must note that the quit rents paid by the farmers are paid to the military authorities. This is unreasonable because if we are heading towards independence, then this land should be taken back by the Government, and whatever is paid by the

Column: 684

farmer should be paid into the Government coffers instead of the military authorities. That means the British are now occupying our land and taking money from our people.

3.00 p.m.

    There is a great deal of land - a few hundred acres - occupied by the Naval Base, and a few hundred acres also occupied by the War Department. Some of this land is not properly used or is never used at all. So the idea put forward by my colleague is a good one.

    Another point arises when land is acquired for general purposes. Some farmers in Geylang Serai are faced with eviction and resettlement in Sembawang. In this respect, I notice that the land given by the Government to these farmers is insufficient for their farming, only about three-quarters of an acre. So if the farmer and his family were to depend on this bit of land, it would not be enough for farming. I hope the Government will consider this matter and give more attention to the needs of the farmers.

    On the average, if a farmer has to maintain his family by farming - say, a family of three or four persons - then at least the piece of land required should be more than an acre in area, otherwise the yield is not sufficient to maintain the farmer and his family. Production from a small piece of land is far too low, and we must give the farmer more land to increase his production. If you force the farmer into the jungle to cultivate a small piece of land, say, three-quarters ---

    The Chairman: Order. We are again going back. I did inform hon. Members not to go back to what should have been discussed yesterday. I have let the hon. Member mention this - to suggest to the Government what use is the land to be put to. I think that is perfectly in order. But to go on developing the theme of the farmer, which should have been developed yesterday, is completely out of order today. Will the Member please remember that?

Column: 685



    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): The other suggestion I wish to make is that there are big landowners in Singapore. I hope that the Government, when acquiring land, will not acquire it from small landowners or small holdings, unless such small holdings are actually necessary for development purposes. If it can be avoided, we should not force the small landowners out of their land.

    There is one company in Sembawang Estate which occupies a big piece of land. The Government has not taken action to acquire it. I suggest that in case of acquisition, the Government should pay more attention to big landowners, because it will then bring in more profit for the people and for the Government. These big landowners will not suffer badly from the acquisition because they are rich. So it is my hope that the Government will pay attention to what I have said.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister has said just now that after merger he was able to take back some 300 acres of land from the British. I do not know whether he will continue to do this in future, that is to say, to get back more land from the military authorities. As a matter of fact, the Member for Jalan Kayu has said that the military authorities are occupying the land of the people of Singapore for no useful purpose at all. This is a point worthy of attention. I think the Prime Minister cannot deny this fact.

    Furthermore, in the areas of land occupied by the military authorities, some bombs may be stored. I do not want this to happen because they can always send their bombs back to England for safe keeping. Our land should be used for farming and other uses so that we can save more money on purchase of land. I think this is a good suggestion worthy of Government's attention.

    The Prime Minister has just said that we have already acquired 300 acres of land and we can forget about the rest of it. This is not proper because,

Column: 686

as a matter of fact, there is still a vast area of land occupied by the British military.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, it is a very sad commentary on the Opposition - flogging all the dead horses, these issues of large and vast tracts of land being captured by the British armed forces, greedily dog-in-the-manger squatting on them. The Member for Hong Lim used to flog this issue in every one of our sessions. We have gone through all that. In 1963 we went through it in London before the final terms on Malaysia - every scrap of land, title to it, user being put to. I welcome any further suggestions from Members of the Opposition in regard to any specific piece of land which they think the Army is not using but just squatting on with a view to denying Singapore its user.

    I would also like to remind Members opposite that there have been some fundamental changes in this situation. The problem that will arise for us in the next decade is what to do when these bases are gradually scrapped away, as they will be in course of time, maybe 10 years, maybe 15 years, but certainly within the next two decades. These are not the problems. The problem in Singapore will still remain - shortage of land. We are a small island of 224 square miles. We are reclaiming land on the east coast; the whole of the foreshore from Bedok to Tanjong Rhu. We are also reclaiming land in the Kallang Basin. We are reclaiming land in Jurong, all the estuaries. We will willingly scrutinise any further better ideas which the Opposition can offer.

    But to suggest, as the Member for Jalan Kayu did, that we should not acquire land belonging to small landlords - it is, of course, the Barisan Sosialis philosophy that small landlords should be protected and land acquired only from the big landlords. We do not want to acquire land unless we have to, and land is acquired not whether it belongs to a small or a big landlord, but whether that particular area needs certain particular facilities or amenities to be provided for, such as

Column: 687

schools, hospitals, roads, circuses, fire brigade, fire stations, and so on. It is irrelevant whether the landlord is a big or a small one. I know the Member for Jalan Kayu considers himself reasonably safe in the definition of "small landowner".

    Finally, I would like to give Members this assurance: that the $10 million will be disbursed in a business-like manner, it is not our duty as the Government to pay more than we have to when we acquire land or to give largesse when removing squatters from Crown land. We understand, Mr Speaker, Sir, that legally we are not bound to give anything away when we ask people to move out from Crown land. They are people who have squatted, encumbered lands. The Member for Bukit Panjang has mentioned the compensation paid as $300/$400. There are certain rules and certain scales - the area of the attap huts, fruit trees, and so on and so forth. This will be worked out. We have never been more generous in the whole of the history of squatter resettlement. We take this as a form of social welfare aid to resettle and rehouse people. But there is a limit. Otherwise we may well and justly be accused of encouraging more squatting on Government land for the purpose of extracting or extorting resettlement prices when the land has to be cleared for development.

    I think these issues have been gone through ad nauseam every time. The problem that still remains is one of insufficient land for the number of people in this island.

    I do not pretend to be able to solve the problem of agricultural land in Singapore. It is one of those problems which are basically insolvable. If we succeed as the industrial base in Malaysia, as we may well do in the next decade, then there is no place for either grazing land or agricultural land in the popularly understood sense of that term. Singapore is an industrial city, and the price of land is being determined on the basis of a developing industrial complex.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

Column: 688



    Head D 02 -

    The Chairman: Head D 02 - Ministry of Finance. There are three amendments under this Head, the first of which stands in the names of Mr Kow Kee Seng and Mr Chia Thye Poh.

    Mr Kow Kee Seng (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for head D 02 he reduced by the whole sum in respect of subhead 002.

    Mr Speaker, in the past when the Prime Minister negotiated on the White Paper Merger, he promised a loan of some $150 million for development purposes in North Borneo, that is to say, Singapore has to pay some $30 million per year for 5 years on condition that North Borneo must employ 50 per cent labour from Singapore. The Prime Minister has mentioned this many times in the past, but according to the Sin Chew Jit Poh of 23rd July, the Chief Minister of North Borneo, Dato Stephens, denied this. On the 25th of July a spokesman for Sarawak denied this again in the Sin Chew Jit Poh of 25th July. In this House on 16th December, 1963, the Finance Minister also mentioned that we were giving some $30 million per year to North Borneo so that it would be able to get some 8,000 labourers from Singapore every year.

3.15 p.m.

    I ask the Minister for Finance whether the promise by North Borneo to engage workers from Singapore still holds good today.

    The second question is whether, at the present juncture, the Singapore Government is continuing negotiations with North Borneo with regard to the employment of labourers from Singapore and their terms of employment.

    The third question is this. If the North Borneo Government finally refuses to engage workers from Singapore, why do we have a provision for next year of a loan of $30 million to the North Borneo Government?

Column: 689



    On 1st November, the newspapers reported that Dato Pang Tet Tshung, the Minister for Social Welfare of Sarawak, said that he was prepared to go to Taiwan to recruit labour. That being so, I ask, why do we have a provision for next year of a loan of $30 million?

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): I am not speaking on the motion.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not responsible for what the newspapers report about what Ministers say. I can only inform the Assembly what I know for a fact.

    The present position is this. Discussions have taken place between officials of the Singapore Government, the Central Government and the Sarawak and Sabah Governments over this matter. The Finance Ministry of the Central Government is making a study of the Development Plan of the North Borneo territories of Sabah and Sarawak to find out how much labour content there is in this Plan; that is to say, if their development proposals are carried out, then how many workers will be involved? On that basis, 50 per cent - it may be more or it may be less - of the workers they will employ in projects financed by the loans made from the Singapore Development Fund will be engaged from Singapore. This is quite a complicated operation. The Ministry of Labour has asked people in the Unemployment Exchange whether or not they were prepared to work in Sabah and Sarawak, and just over 8,000 persons have said that they were prepared to go there. Therefore, the Singapore Government is making plans to establish reception areas in Kuching, Jesselton, Sandakan and I think at one or two other points, so that these people who want to work there can be sent there at Government's expense and live there until the call for their employment is made. We have agreed with the Central Government and the Sabah and Sarawak Governments that the cost of sending workers from Singapore to the Borneo territories and the cost of maintaining them until they find work

Column: 690

will be borne by the Singapore Government. If once they are found unsuitable after employment, then the cost of repatriating them back to Singapore will be borne by the Borneo Government concerned.

    As I have said, this is a very complicated operation. The officials of the four Governments concerned - the Central Government, the Singapore Government and the Sabah and Sarawak Governments - are working out the details and I hope that we can reach an early and satisfactory solution to this problem. If we can find jobs for 8,000 of our citizens in Sabah and Sarawak sometime next year, I think this will be a worthwhile achievement to relieve a lot of the distress and enforced idleness among our young men and women. I do not think that this is too high a price for extending a $20 million interest-free loan and a $10 million loan with interest.
